name: Visual Supports
description: Using images, diagrams, and symbols to help students understand and retain new language and content by providing visual context and scaffolding for comprehension.
implementation_steps: Use graphic organizers like mind maps or Venn diagrams; Label classroom objects and walls with vocabulary; Provide visual schedules to help students understand the flow of the lesson; Create picture dictionaries for new vocabulary; Use charts and posters to display language structures
materials: Graphic organizers; Labels and tape; Poster paper; Markers; Digital presentation tools; Picture cards; Visual schedule templates
research_basis: Dual Coding Theory (Paivio, 1971, 1986) supports that visual and verbal information are processed differently in separate channels, and combining both enhances learning and retention. Research shows dual coding improves memory and comprehension compared to single-modality instruction

name: Multimodal Learning
description: Engaging multiple senses (visual, auditory, kinesthetic) to reinforce learning by providing information through various channels to accommodate different learning styles and strengthen neural pathways.
implementation_steps: Use videos, songs, and podcasts to introduce new content; Have students draw pictures or act out key concepts; Encourage students to create multimedia projects such as videos or posters; Incorporate movement and gestures with vocabulary; Use manipulatives for hands-on learning
materials: Videos; Audio equipment; Art supplies; Recording devices; Computers or tablets; Manipulatives; Musical instruments; Props for acting
research_basis: Research in cognitive psychology shows that engaging multiple sensory modalities increases retention and comprehension rates

name: Frayer Model
description: A four-square graphic organizer that helps students define a word, give examples and non-examples, and identify characteristics to build deep vocabulary understanding.
implementation_steps: Introduce the Frayer Model template with four squares; Have students write the target word in the center; Students fill in definition, characteristics, examples, and non-examples; Discuss and share completed organizers; Use for both content and academic vocabulary
materials: Frayer Model templates; Pencils or pens; Dictionary access; Whiteboard or chart paper; Content-specific vocabulary lists
research_basis: Research shows that teaching vocabulary through multiple contexts and connections improves long-term retention and transfer

name: KWL Chart
description: A three-column chart (Know, Want to Know, Learned) that helps students activate prior knowledge, set learning goals, and track their learning progress throughout a lesson or unit.
implementation_steps: Create three-column chart with K-W-L headers; Have students brainstorm what they already know about the topic; Students generate questions about what they want to learn; After instruction, students record what they learned; Compare new learning with initial questions and knowledge
materials: KWL chart templates; Writing materials; Whiteboard or poster paper; Access to content materials; Sticky notes for individual responses
research_basis: Constructivist learning theory emphasizes the importance of connecting new information to prior knowledge for meaningful learning

name: T-Chart Comparison
description: A simple two-column organizer used to compare and contrast ideas, concepts, or vocabulary, helping students organize information and see relationships between concepts.
implementation_steps: Draw or provide T-Chart template with two columns; Label columns with comparison categories; Have students fill in information for each side; Discuss similarities and differences; Use for various subjects like comparing characters, cultures, or problem-solving methods
materials: T-Chart templates; Writing materials; Content examples; Whiteboard; Comparison topics or prompts
research_basis: Comparative analysis helps students develop critical thinking skills and deeper understanding of content relationships

name: Action Verb Movement
description: A language teaching method that integrates physical movement to reinforce language concepts, particularly effective for learning action vocabulary through kinesthetic engagement.
implementation_steps: Introduce new action verbs with demonstrations; Have students repeat actions while saying the words; Practice commands using TPR (Stand up, sit down, walk, run); Create action sequences for students to follow; Use TPR with songs or chants containing action words
materials: List of action verbs; Open space for movement; Visual verb cards; Music for action songs; Props for different actions
research_basis: Kinesthetic learning theory shows that physical movement enhances memory formation and language acquisition

name: Command Response Training
description: Using physical movement to respond to verbal instructions, helping students understand language through action while building listening comprehension and vocabulary.
implementation_steps: Give simple one-step commands initially; Progress to multi-step instructions; Use TPR with classroom directions; Have students give commands to peers; Incorporate TPR into daily routines and transitions
materials: Instruction cards; Props for commands; Space for movement; Visual cues for complex instructions; Timer for activities
research_basis: Research shows that TPR reduces anxiety and increases engagement while supporting comprehension through physical response

name: Body Parts Identification
description: A kinesthetic approach to learning body part vocabulary where students physically touch or point to body parts as they learn the corresponding vocabulary words.
implementation_steps: Teach body part names with pointing and touching; Have students touch body parts as you name them; Students give commands to touch body parts; Create body part songs with movements; Use Simon Says game with body parts
materials: Body part vocabulary cards; Songs or chants; Anatomical charts; Mirrors for self-identification; Simon Says instruction cards
research_basis: Kinesthetic vocabulary learning creates stronger neural pathways and improves retention compared to passive learning methods

name: Phonics Games
description: Focusing on the relationship between letters and sounds through engaging games that help students decode and pronounce words systematically.
implementation_steps: Use letter-sound matching games; Practice rhyming games with picture cards; Implement sound sorting activities; Play phonics bingo with letter sounds; Create word building games with magnetic letters
materials: Letter cards; Picture cards; Magnetic letters; Phonics games; Sound charts; Rhyming books; Bingo cards with letters/sounds
research_basis: Systematic phonics instruction has strong research support for developing reading skills in both native speakers and English learners

name: Word Family Patterns
description: Teaching groups of words that share the same ending pattern (rime) to help students recognize sound patterns, spelling rules, and improve decoding fluency.
implementation_steps: Introduce word family pattern (-at, -an, -ing); Show examples of words in the family; Have students generate additional words; Practice reading word family lists; Create word family wheels or flip books; Use word families in simple sentences
materials: Word family cards; Flip books; Word wheels; Magnetic letters; Phonics readers; Chart paper; Markers; Word family worksheets
research_basis: Word family instruction helps students recognize patterns and chunks in words, leading to more efficient reading and spelling

name: Content Links Prediction
description: Using strategic vocabulary from a text to activate prior knowledge, facilitate prediction, and practice syntax through collaborative sentence building.
implementation_steps: Teacher selects key vocabulary from a text; Teacher writes/prints each word on a small piece of paper; Teacher distributes a word to each student/pair of students/small group of students; Teacher directs students to mingle then form a group to create a sentence with three of the words; Each group shares their sentence with the rest of the class; Teacher directs students to mingle again then form another group to create a sentence with five of the words; Each group shares their sentence with the rest of the class; Teacher can challenge students to create a sentence with even more words; Teacher points out syntax as students share their sentences, predicting the content of the text
materials: Target text; paper/card stock; pens/markers; whiteboard
research_basis: Builds on Schema Theory, helping students connect new information to existing knowledge. Collaborative, multimodal engagement strengthens memory pathways

name: Interactive Read-Aloud
description: A paired reading strategy where students take turns reading and summarizing to improve fluency, comprehension, and active listening.
implementation_steps: Partner A reads first paragraph; Partner B summarizes; Partner B reads second paragraph; Partner A summarizes; Process continues for the entire text
materials: Reading text; partner assignments; timer (optional)
research_basis: This reciprocal teaching strategy creates a multimodal experience. Research shows that reading aloud and explaining concepts can improve memory and comprehension

name: Collaborative Summary
description: A small-group task where students work together to distill the main ideas of a text into a single, concise sentence, fostering critical analysis and consensus.
implementation_steps: Students read a text individually or as a group; In small groups, they discuss the main ideas; Groups collaborate to write a single summary sentence of 20 words or less; Groups share their sentences with the class; If time remains, groups refine their summary to 12 words or less
materials: Text; writing materials; whiteboard or chart paper for sharing; word counter
research_basis: The act of summarizing and explaining concepts to peers requires deep cognitive processing, which strengthens comprehension and long-term retention

name: Phonological Awareness Instruction
description: Explicit teaching of the ability to recognize and manipulate the sound structure of oral language, including words, syllables, onset-rime, and phonemes, which serves as the foundation for phonics instruction.
implementation_steps: Teach rhyming with songs and nursery rhymes; Practice identifying words in sentences; Work on syllable identification and segmentation; Teach onset-rime blending and segmentation; Progress to phoneme-level work including isolation, blending, segmentation, deletion, and substitution; Use age-appropriate materials starting simple and building complexity
materials: Rhyming books and songs; Picture cards; Sound counters or chips; Elkonin boxes for sound mapping; Mirrors for articulation; Word and syllable cards
research_basis: According to the California Dyslexia Guidelines, phonological awareness is essential foundation for phonics. Difficulty in phonological awareness, especially phonemic awareness, is a key predictor of dyslexia. The guidelines specify this is one of the essential components of reading instruction per federal law Section 6368(3) of Title 20

name: Phonemic Awareness Training
description: Direct instruction in the most advanced phonological awareness skill - the ability to manipulate individual phonemes (discrete sounds) within words through blending, segmentation, and manipulation.
implementation_steps: Teach phoneme isolation (identify first, last, and medial sounds in words); Practice phoneme blending (blend individual sounds like /c/ /a/ /t/ into cat); Teach phoneme segmentation (break cat into /c/ /a/ /t/); Practice phoneme deletion (say skip without /k/ to get sip); Practice phoneme substitution (change /c/ in cat to /b/ to make bat); Use visual supports like Elkonin boxes; Provide immediate corrective feedback
materials: Elkonin boxes; Phoneme counters; Picture cards; Letter tiles; Sound cards; Mirrors for articulation feedback
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines state phonemic awareness is the component of phonological processing most directly linked to acquisition of decoding and spelling skills. It is a prerequisite for understanding phonics and facilitates understanding of the place value of graphemes and phonemes within words

name: Letter-Sound Association (Phonics)
description: Systematic and explicit instruction in grapheme-phoneme (letter to sound) and phoneme-grapheme (sound to letter) correspondences that form the foundation for decoding and encoding.
implementation_steps: Teach individual letter sounds systematically; Show how letters represent sounds in words; Practice associating graphemes with phonemes for reading; Practice associating phonemes with graphemes for spelling; Use multisensory techniques; Teach patterns from simple to complex; Provide cumulative practice with previously taught patterns; Include both real words and decodable pseudo-words
materials: Letter cards; Sound charts; Decodable texts; Phonics readers; Magnetic letters; Whiteboards; Markers; Pseudo-word lists for practice
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines identify that students with dyslexia have significant difficulty acquiring sound-letter and letter-sound correspondences due to deficits in phonological processing. The guidelines specify phonics is one of the essential components of reading instruction per federal law Section 6368(3) of Title 20

name: Rapid Naming Practice
description: Timed practice in quickly naming letters, numbers, colors, or objects to build retrieval speed and reading fluency, targeting a specific phonological processing component.
implementation_steps: Use standardized rapid naming cards with letters, numbers, colors, or objects arranged in rows; Time students as they name items as quickly as possible; Record baseline and track progress over time; Practice daily in short sessions (2-3 minutes); Start with object/color naming for young students who don't know letters yet; Progress to letter and number naming
materials: Rapid automatized naming (RAN) assessment cards or charts; Stopwatch or timer; Progress tracking forms; Letter/number/color/object stimulus cards
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines identify rapid naming as one of three major components of phonological processing. The guidelines state that individuals with deficits in both rapid naming and phonemic awareness have greater difficulty learning to read

name: Vocabulary Development Instruction
description: Systematic teaching of word meanings through multiple exposures, contexts, and connections to support reading comprehension and language development.
implementation_steps: Pre-teach key vocabulary before reading; Provide student-friendly definitions; Show words in multiple meaningful contexts; Teach word relationships (synonyms, antonyms, categories); Provide 7-12 exposures to each word through varied activities; Connect to students' background knowledge; Use words in speaking and writing; Teach vocabulary learning strategies; Assess understanding regularly
materials: Vocabulary word lists; Picture supports; Context sentence examples; Graphic organizers for word relationships; Vocabulary notebooks; Word cards; Interactive word walls
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines list vocabulary development as one of the essential components of reading instruction per federal law Section 6368(3) of Title 20

name: Reading Fluency Instruction
description: Teaching accurate, automatic, and prosodic (expressive) oral reading through modeling, guided practice, and repeated readings to support comprehension.
implementation_steps: Model fluent reading with appropriate expression and pacing; Use repeated readings of same text; Provide assisted reading (choral, paired, audio-assisted); Set fluency goals and monitor progress; Use appropriately leveled texts; Teach attention to punctuation and phrasing; Provide corrective feedback on accuracy and expression; Practice with decodable texts that match phonics instruction
materials: Appropriately leveled texts; Decodable readers; Fluency passages; Timer; Fluency tracking charts; Audio recordings of fluent reading; Expression guides or rubrics
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines identify reading fluency including oral reading skills as one of the essential components of reading instruction per federal law Section 6368(3) of Title 20

name: Reading Comprehension Strategy Instruction
description: Explicit teaching of strategies to understand and interpret text, including both literal and inferential comprehension of narrative and expository texts.
implementation_steps: Teach comprehension strategies explicitly (predicting, questioning, clarifying, summarizing, visualizing, making connections); Model strategy use with think-alouds; Provide guided practice with scaffolding; Use graphic organizers to organize thinking; Teach text structure awareness; Ask literal and inferential questions; Monitor comprehension during reading; Teach fix-up strategies when comprehension breaks down
materials: Texts at appropriate levels; Comprehension strategy bookmarks or posters; Graphic organizers; Question stems for different comprehension levels; Think-aloud guides; Sticky notes for marking text
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines identify reading comprehension strategies as one of the essential components of reading instruction per federal law Section 6368(3) of Title 20

name: Spelling (Encoding) Instruction
description: Systematic teaching of how to spell words by connecting sounds to letters (phoneme-grapheme association), reinforcing the reciprocal relationship between reading and spelling.
implementation_steps: Teach phoneme-grapheme associations systematically; Practice spelling words that follow taught patterns; Use word sorts by spelling patterns; Teach spelling rules and generalizations; Include dictation activities; Analyze spelling errors to identify patterns; Practice spelling both in isolation and in context of writing; Use multisensory spelling techniques; Assess spelling of both real words and pseudo-words
materials: Spelling word lists aligned to phonics instruction; Dictation materials; Word sort cards; Spelling notebooks; Whiteboards for practice; Sound boxes for phoneme-grapheme mapping
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines state that students with dyslexia are characterized by poor spelling and decoding abilities. Spelling is almost always affected in dyslexia

name: Handwriting Instruction
description: Direct teaching of letter formation, pencil grasp, spacing, and legibility to support written expression and reduce cognitive load during writing tasks.
implementation_steps: Teach proper pencil grasp and posture; Model correct letter formation; Practice writing letters using consistent verbal pathway; Use lined paper with appropriate spacing; Teach starting points and directionality for each letter; Practice letter formation with multisensory techniques (sand trays, tactile surfaces); Address reversals through explicit instruction; Practice fluent letter formation
materials: Lined paper with appropriate sizing; Pencils and grips; Letter formation guides; Multisensory materials; Whiteboards; Models of correctly formed letters; Verbal pathway cues posted
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines include handwriting as a component to assess and address. Students may show poor penmanship, difficulty using mature pencil grasp, and difficulty with space on page

name: Written Expression Instruction
description: Teaching the process of composing text including planning, organizing, drafting, revising, and editing to communicate ideas effectively in writing.
implementation_steps: Teach writing process stages explicitly; Use graphic organizers for planning; Provide sentence starters and frames; Model writing with think-alouds; Teach paragraph and essay structure; Address grammar, punctuation, and capitalization; Provide time for drafting and revising; Give specific feedback; Allow use of assistive technology when appropriate
materials: Graphic organizers for planning; Sentence frames; Writing rubrics; Mentor texts; Grammar references; Editing checklists; Word processing tools; Speech-to-text tools when appropriate
research_basis: California Dyslexia Guidelines note that students with dyslexia often have difficulties with written expression. Difficulties organizing ideas for writing are common

name: Comprehensible Input
description: Adjusting teacher speech and language to make content understandable for English learners by controlling rate, restating key vocabulary, and using gestures to support meaning-making.
implementation_steps: Monitor and adjust your rate of speech to allow processing time; Restate key academic vocabulary multiple times during instruction; Provide gestures or motions when possible to assist understanding; Check for understanding frequently; Use visuals paired with oral language; Repeat important concepts in different ways
materials: Timer or self-monitoring checklist; Key vocabulary list for lesson; Visual gestures guide; Comprehensible input strategies poster
research_basis: Krashen's Input Hypothesis (1982, 2003) states that language acquisition occurs when learners receive comprehensible input - language that is understandable but slightly above current proficiency (i+1). Research shows comprehensible input is the necessary condition for second language acquisition

name: Picture File Cards (GLAD)
description: Using real photographs to help students make meaning of important vocabulary or topics through visual support, particularly for words or concepts with low access points.
implementation_steps: Review upcoming lesson content; Anticipate which words, people, or concepts might have low access points for students; Use internet searches to locate real photos (not clipart); Cut out or prepare photos; Display picture file cards during lesson when introducing or discussing the vocabulary or concept; Pair verbal instruction with visual reference
materials: Real photographs; Construction paper or card stock; Scissors; Glue or tape; Digital display option; Picture file card storage system
research_basis: Project GLAD has demonstrated effectiveness in improving literacy outcomes for English learners (Deussen et al., 2014, ERIC ED562842). Picture file cards are one of GLAD's 35 research-based strategies (Source: Campbell ELD Presentation)

name: Observation Charts (GLAD)
description: An interactive chart strategy where students gallery walk to write observations, prior knowledge, or questions about picture file cards related to a topic.
implementation_steps: Prepare 5-6 pieces of construction paper with picture file cards related to topic; Tape blank paper next to each picture; Model how to use observation chart; Divide students into small groups; Have groups gallery walk; Students write and/or sketch their observations, knowledge, or questions; Debrief as whole class
materials: Construction paper; Picture file cards; Blank paper; Tape; Markers or pencils; Timer for rotations
research_basis: Project GLAD has demonstrated effectiveness in cluster randomized trial (Deussen et al., 2014, ERIC ED562842). Observation Charts are one of GLAD's strategies for comprehensible input (Source: Campbell ELD Presentation)

name: Sentence Patterning Chart (GLAD)
description: A color-coded chart that displays sentence structures with parts of speech organized by columns allowing students to build and practice varied sentence patterns.
implementation_steps: Create chart with columns for different parts of speech; Color code each column; Fill chart with words from lesson content; Model building sentences by selecting words from different columns; Have students practice building their own sentences; Use gestures or movements for different parts of speech; Practice with choral response; Apply to writing tasks
materials: Large chart paper; Colored markers (4 colors minimum); Content vocabulary organized by part of speech; Sentence building practice sheets; Visual part of speech references
research_basis: Project GLAD effectiveness demonstrated in improving literacy outcomes for English learners (Deussen et al., 2014). Sentence Patterning Charts provide structured scaffolding (Source: Campbell ELD Presentation, Be GLAD training)

name: Color Coding for Parts of Speech
description: A visual strategy that uses different colors to identify and categorize parts of speech to help students build sentence structure knowledge.
implementation_steps: Select consistent colors for each part of speech; Teach each part of speech explicitly with color association; Have students highlight or underline parts of speech in text using designated colors; Color code word banks or word walls; Practice building sentences using color-coded words; Apply color coding to student writing
materials: Colored highlighters; Colored pencils or markers; Color-coded word banks; Anchor charts; Text passages for practice; Color-coded sentence building strips
research_basis: Part of GLAD methodology showing effectiveness for English learners (Deussen et al., 2014). Color coding assists grammar understanding (Source: Campbell ELD Presentation)

name: Choral Response
description: A speaking practice strategy where the whole class or small group repeats academic language together to build vocabulary, pronunciation, and confidence.
implementation_steps: Identify key vocabulary words, definitions, or phrases for choral practice; Use clear cue phrases like 'My turn, your turn'; Teacher models pronunciation and students repeat in unison; Practice with individual words, then definitions, then complete phrases; Use throughout lesson; Incorporate gestures or movements; Provide multiple repetitions
materials: Academic vocabulary word list; Cue phrase posters; Visual vocabulary cards; Gestures or motions for key terms; Timer for brief practice sessions
research_basis: Oral language practice through repetition and modeling supports vocabulary acquisition and reduces anxiety for English learners (California ELD Standards, GLAD training materials)

name: Turn and Talk
description: A quick paired discussion strategy where students share ideas with a partner about a specific topic or question to activate prior knowledge and practice oral language.
implementation_steps: Pose a specific question or topic; Give clear time limit (30-60 seconds per partner); Have students turn to face their partner; Each partner takes a turn sharing; Signal when time is up; Ask a few pairs to share with whole group; Use regularly throughout lessons
materials: Discussion prompts or questions; Timer; Partner pairing system; Sentence frames for discussion (optional); Signal for attention
research_basis: Think-Pair-Share enhances critical thinking (Kaddoura, 2013, ERIC EJ1061947). Education Endowment Foundation reports collaborative learning has moderate impact based on extensive evidence (Source: Campbell ELD Presentation)

name: Multimodal Response Options
description: Providing multiple ways for students to demonstrate understanding by allowing responses through drawing, speaking orally, pointing, or writing.
implementation_steps: Explain task or question clearly; Offer choice of response modes: drawing, oral response, pointing, or written response; Provide sentence frames or word banks for support; Allow students to use mode that best matches their language proficiency; Accept and validate all response types; Gradually encourage more complex language production
materials: Drawing paper and materials; Sentence frames; Word banks; Response boards; Visual answer choices; Recording tools; Scaffolded writing templates
research_basis: Universal Design for Learning (UDL) research emphasizes multiple means of expression. Allowing varied response modes provides access for English learners at different proficiency levels while maintaining cognitive demand

name: Highlighting Key Content
description: A visual strategy where teachers pre-highlight key portions of text or students highlight key academic vocabulary during reading.
implementation_steps: Pre-read text and identify key information; Use highlighter to mark important passages, vocabulary, or concepts; Provide highlighted text to students as reference; OR: Teach students to highlight key academic vocabulary as they read; Post highlighted vocabulary for visual reference; Use consistent highlighting system; Practice highlighting strategies with guided instruction
materials: Highlighters (multiple colors); Text passages at appropriate level; Vocabulary lists; Highlighting guide; Anchor chart showing highlighting system; Sticky notes as alternative
research_basis: Research on metacognitive strategies shows highlighting key information supports reading comprehension and helps students identify important content. Pre-highlighting provides scaffolding for English learners

name: Posted Learning Objectives
description: Displaying lesson objectives in written form and reading them aloud to students so they understand the purpose and goals of the lesson.
implementation_steps: Write clear, student-friendly learning objective; Display objective prominently; Read objective aloud to students at start of lesson; Use 'I will' or 'Students will' format; Refer back to objective during and at end of lesson; Have students restate objective; Check at lesson end whether objective was met
materials: Whiteboard, chart paper, or digital display; Pre-written objectives; Student-friendly language; Objective template or format guide
research_basis: John Hattie's Visible Learning research (2009, 2011) found Teacher Clarity has an effect size of 0.75. Clear learning intentions are core components of teacher clarity (Source: Campbell ELD Presentation)

name: Visual Input Charts (GLAD)
description: Large charts combining text and images to teach content concepts, making information comprehensible through visual and verbal input together.
implementation_steps: Create large chart with lesson content; Combine written text with images, diagrams, or illustrations; Use color and visual organization; Introduce chart with picture walk; Read and discuss chart with students using gestures; Leave chart posted for ongoing reference; Have students interact with chart; Use chart for multiple lessons and reviews
materials: Large chart paper; Markers in multiple colors; Images or picture file cards; Content text; Tape or clips for posting; Storage for reusable charts
research_basis: GLAD methodology emphasizes visual input charts provide comprehensible input by combining visual and verbal information. Dual-coding approach enhances learning for English learners

name: Cooperative Group Roles
description: Assigning specific roles to group members to structure collaborative work and ensure equitable participation.
implementation_steps: Introduce each cooperative role with clear responsibilities; Model what each role looks like and sounds like; Assign roles to group members or allow groups to select roles; Provide role cards or visual reminders; Rotate roles regularly; Monitor groups and provide feedback; Debrief about role effectiveness after group work
materials: Role cards; Role badges or identifiers; Group work task sheet; Timer; Anchor chart with role descriptions; Reflection sheet for role performance
research_basis: Johnson & Johnson's meta-analysis of 164 studies found cooperative learning methods had significant positive impact (Johnson, Johnson, & Stanne, 2000). Effect sizes: cooperative vs competitive = 0.49, cooperative vs individualistic = 0.53 (Source: Campbell ELD Presentation)

name: Modeling and Demonstration
description: Explicitly showing students what you want them to do through visual examples, role play, or step-by-step demonstration.
implementation_steps: Clearly explain what students will be learning to do; Demonstrate the complete process or task; Think aloud as you model; Use document camera, poster, or role play; Provide visual example of completed task for reference; Break complex tasks into steps and model each; Answer questions about the process; Provide guided practice before independent work
materials: Document camera or visualizer; Example work samples; Materials for demonstration; Step-by-step visual guide; Posters or anchor charts; Role play props if applicable
research_basis: Research on explicit instruction shows modeling and demonstration are essential for learning complex tasks. For English learners, visual modeling reduces language demands while maintaining access to content (Source: Campbell ELD Presentation)
